012package org.postgresql.pljava.example.annotation;

014import java.sql.Connection;
015import static java.sql.DriverManager.getConnection;
016import java.sql.ResultSet;
017import java.sql.SQLException;
018import java.sql.Statement;
019
020import java.util.ArrayList;
021import java.util.Arrays;
022import static java.util.Arrays.deepToString;
023import java.util.Iterator;
024import java.util.List;
025import java.util.Objects;
026import java.util.Optional;
027
028import java.time.LocalDateTime;
029
030import org.postgresql.pljava.Adapter;
031import org.postgresql.pljava.Adapter.AdapterException;//for now; not planned API
032import org.postgresql.pljava.Adapter.As;
033import org.postgresql.pljava.Adapter.AsLong;
034import org.postgresql.pljava.Adapter.AsDouble;
035import org.postgresql.pljava.Adapter.AsInt;
036import org.postgresql.pljava.Adapter.AsFloat;
037import org.postgresql.pljava.Adapter.AsShort;
038import org.postgresql.pljava.Adapter.AsChar;
039import org.postgresql.pljava.Adapter.AsByte;
040import org.postgresql.pljava.Adapter.AsBoolean;
041import org.postgresql.pljava.ResultSetProvider;
042import org.postgresql.pljava.TargetList;
043import org.postgresql.pljava.TargetList.Cursor;
044import org.postgresql.pljava.TargetList.Projection;
045
046import org.postgresql.pljava.annotation.Function;
047import static
048    org.postgresql.pljava.annotation.Function.OnNullInput.RETURNS_NULL;
049import org.postgresql.pljava.annotation.SQLAction;
050
051import org.postgresql.pljava.model.Attribute;
052import org.postgresql.pljava.model.Portal;
053import static org.postgresql.pljava.model.Portal.ALL;
054import static org.postgresql.pljava.model.Portal.Direction.FORWARD;
055import org.postgresql.pljava.model.SlotTester;
056import org.postgresql.pljava.model.TupleDescriptor;
057import org.postgresql.pljava.model.TupleTableSlot;
058
059/**
060 * A temporary test jig during TupleTableSlot development; intended
061 * to be used from a debugger.
062 */
063@SQLAction(requires = "modelToJDBC", install =
064"WITH" +
065" result AS (" +
066"  SELECT" +
067"    * " +
068"   FROM" +
069"    javatest.modelToJDBC(" +
070"     'SELECT DISTINCT" +
071"       CAST ( relacl AS text ), relacl" +
072"      FROM" +
073"       pg_class" +
074"      WHERE" +
075"       relacl IS NOT NULL'," +
076"     'org.postgresql.pljava.pg.adt.TextAdapter',  'INSTANCE'," +
077"     'org.postgresql.pljava.pg.adt.GrantAdapter', 'LIST_INSTANCE'" +
078"    ) AS r(raw text, cooked text)" +
079" )," +
080" conformed AS (" +
081"  SELECT" +
082"    raw, translate(cooked, '[] ', '{}') AS cooked" +
083"   FROM" +
084"    result" +
085" )" +
086" SELECT" +
087"   CASE WHEN every(raw = cooked)" +
088"   THEN javatest.logmessage('INFO', 'AclItem[] ok')" +
089"   ELSE javatest.logmessage('WARNING', 'AclItem[] ng')" +
090"   END" +
091"  FROM" +
092"   conformed"
093)
094@SQLAction(requires = "modelToJDBC", install =
095"WITH" +
096" result AS (" +
097"  SELECT" +
098"    raw, cooked, CAST ( cooked AS numeric ) AS refried" +
099"   FROM" +
100"    javatest.modeltojdbc(" +
101"     'SELECT" +
102"       CAST ( pow AS text ) AS txt, pow AS bin" +
103"      FROM" +
104"       generate_series(-20., 20., 1.) AS gs(p)," +
105"       (VALUES (1e-16), (1e-65)) AS pf(f)," +
106"       (VALUES (1.), (-1.)) AS sf(sgn)," +
107"       LATERAL (SELECT sgn*(37.821637 ^ (p + f))) AS s(pow)'," +
108"     'org.postgresql.pljava.pg.adt.TextAdapter', 'INSTANCE'," +
109"     'org.postgresql.pljava.pg.adt.NumericAdapter', 'BIGDECIMAL_INSTANCE'" +
110"    ) AS j(raw text, cooked text)" +
111" )" +
112" SELECT" +
113"   CASE WHEN every(raw = cooked OR raw = CAST ( refried AS text ))" +
114"   THEN javatest.logmessage('INFO', 'NUMERIC ok')" +
115"   ELSE javatest.logmessage('WARNING', 'NUMERIC ng')" +
116"   END" +
117"  FROM" +
118"   result"
119)
120@SQLAction(requires = "tupleTableSlotTest", install =
121"SELECT" +
122" javatest.tupletableslottest(" +
123"  'SELECT most_common_vals FROM pg_catalog.pg_stats'," +
124"  'org.postgresql.pljava.pg.adt.ArrayAdapter', 'TYPE_OBTAINING_INSTANCE')"
125)
126public class TupleTableSlotTest
127{
128    /*
129     * Collect some Adapter instances that are going to be useful in the code
130     * below. Is it necessary they be static final? No, they can be obtained at
131     * any time, but collecting these here will keep the example methods tidier
132     * below.
133     *
134     * These are "leaf" adapters: they work from the PostgreSQL types directly.
135     */
136    static final AsLong   <       ?> INT8;
137    static final AsInt    <       ?> INT4;
138    static final AsShort  <       ?> INT2;
139    static final AsByte   <       ?> INT1;
140    static final AsDouble <       ?> FLOAT8;
141    static final AsFloat  <       ?> FLOAT4;
142    static final AsBoolean<       ?> BOOL;
143
144    static final As<String       ,?> TEXT;
145    static final As<LocalDateTime,?> LDT;  // for the PostgreSQL TIMESTAMP type
146
147    /*
148     * Now some adapters that can be derived from leaf adapters by composing
149     * non-leaf adapters over them.
150     *
151     * By default, the Adapters for primitive types can't fetch a null
152     * value. There is no value in the primitive's value space that could
153     * unambiguously represent null, and a DBMS should not go and reuse an
154     * otherwise-valid value to also mean null, if you haven't said to. But in
155     * a case where that is what you want, it is simple to write an adapter with
156     * the wanted behavior and compose it over the original one.
157     */
158    static final AsDouble<?> F8_NaN; // primitive double using NaN for null
159
160    /*
161     * Reference-typed adapters have no trouble with null values by default;
162     * they'll just produce Java null. But suppose it is more convenient to get
163     * an Optional<LocalDateTime> instead of a LocalDateTime that might be null.
164     * An Adapter for that can be obtained by composition.
165     */
166    static final As<Optional<LocalDateTime>,?> LDT_O;
167
168    /*
169     * A composing adapter expecting a reference type can also be composed
170     * over one that produces a primitive type. It will see the values
171     * automatically boxed.
172     *
173     * Corollary: should the desired behavior be not to produce Optional,
174     * but simply to enable null handling for a primitive type by producing
175     * its boxed form or null, just one absolutely trivial composing adapter
176     * could add that behavior over any primitive adapter.
177     */
178    static final As<Optional<Long>         ,?> INT8_O;
179
180    /*
181     * Once properly-typed adapters for component types are in hand,
182     * getting properly-typed array adapters is straightforward. (In Java 10+,
183     * a person might prefer to set these up at run time in local variables,
184     * where var could be used instead of these longwinded declarations.)
185     *
186     * For fun, I8x1 will be built over INT8_O, so it will really produce
187     * Optional<Long>[] instead of long[]. F8x5 will be built over F8_NaN, so it
188     * will produce double[][][][][], but null elements won't be rejected,
189     * and will appear as NaN. DTx2 will be built over LDT_O, so it will really
190     * produce Optional<LocalDateTime>[][].
191     */
192    static final As<Optional<Long>[]           ,?> I8x1;
193    static final As<           int[][]         ,?> I4x2;
194    static final As<         short[][][]       ,?> I2x3;
195    static final As<          byte[][][][]     ,?> I1x4;
196    static final As<        double[][][][][]   ,?> F8x5;
197    static final As<         float[][][][][][] ,?> F4x6;
198    static final As<       boolean[][][][][]   ,?>  Bx5;
199    static final As<Optional<LocalDateTime>[][],?> DTx2;
200
201    static
202    {
203        /*
204         * This is the very untidy part, while the planned Adapter manager API
205         * is not yet implemented. The extremely temporary adapterPlease method
206         * can be used to grovel some adapters out of PL/Java's innards, as long
207         * as the name of a class and a static final field is known.
208         *
209         * The adapter manager will have generic methods to obtain adapters with
210         * specific compile-time types. The adapterPlease method, not so much.
211         * It needs to be used with ugly casts.
212         */
213        try
214        {
215            Connection conn = getConnection("jdbc:default:connection");
216            SlotTester t = conn.unwrap(SlotTester.class);
217
218            String cls = "org.postgresql.pljava.pg.adt.Primitives";
219            INT8   = (AsLong   <?>)t.adapterPlease(cls,    "INT8_INSTANCE");
220            INT4   = (AsInt    <?>)t.adapterPlease(cls,    "INT4_INSTANCE");
221            INT2   = (AsShort  <?>)t.adapterPlease(cls,    "INT2_INSTANCE");
222            INT1   = (AsByte   <?>)t.adapterPlease(cls,    "INT1_INSTANCE");
223            FLOAT8 = (AsDouble <?>)t.adapterPlease(cls,  "FLOAT8_INSTANCE");
224            FLOAT4 = (AsFloat  <?>)t.adapterPlease(cls,  "FLOAT4_INSTANCE");
225            BOOL   = (AsBoolean<?>)t.adapterPlease(cls, "BOOLEAN_INSTANCE");
226
227            cls = "org.postgresql.pljava.pg.adt.TextAdapter";
228
229            /*
230             * SuppressWarnings must appear on a declaration, making it hard to
231             * apply here, an initial assignment to a final field declared
232             * earlier. But making this the declaration of a new local variable,
233             * with the actual wanted assignment as a "side effect", works.
234             * (The "unnamed variable" _ previewed in Java 21 would be ideal.)
235             */
236                    @SuppressWarnings("unchecked") Object _1 =
237            TEXT   = (As<String,?>)t.adapterPlease(cls, "INSTANCE");
238
239            cls = "org.postgresql.pljava.pg.adt.DateTimeAdapter$JSR310";
240
241                    @SuppressWarnings("unchecked") Object _2 =
242            LDT    =
243                (As<LocalDateTime,?>)t.adapterPlease(cls, "TIMESTAMP_INSTANCE");
244        }
245        catch ( SQLException | ReflectiveOperationException e )
246        {
247            throw new ExceptionInInitializerError(e);
248        }
249
250        /*
251         * Other than those stopgap uses of adapterPlease, the rest is
252         * not so bad. Instantiate some composing adapters over the leaf
253         * adapters already obtained:
254         */
255
256        F8_NaN = new NullReplacingDouble(FLOAT8, Double.NaN);
257         LDT_O = new AsOptional<>(LDT);
258        INT8_O = new AsOptional<>(INT8);
259
260        /*
261         * (Those composing adapters should be provided by PL/Java and known
262         * to the adapter manager so it can compose them for you. For now,
263         * they are just defined in this example file, showing that client
264         * code can easily supply its own.)
265         *
266         * Java array-of-array adapters of various dimensionalities are
267         * easily built from the adapters chosen for their component types.
268         */
269
270        I8x1 = INT8_O             .a1() .build(); // array of Optional<Long>
271        I4x2 =   INT4       .a2()       .build();
272        I2x3 =   INT2       .a2() .a1() .build();
273        I1x4 =   INT1 .a4()             .build();
274        F8x5 = F8_NaN .a4()       .a1() .build(); // 5D F8 array, null <-> NaN
275        F4x6 = FLOAT4 .a4() .a2()       .build();
276         Bx5 =   BOOL .a4()       .a1() .build();
277        DTx2 =  LDT_O       .a2()       .build(); // 2D of optional LDT
278    }
279
280    /**
281     * Test {@link TargetList} and its functional API for retrieving values.
282     */
283    @Function(schema="javatest")
284    public static Iterator<String> targetListTest()
285    throws SQLException, ReflectiveOperationException
286    {
287        try (
288            Connection conn = getConnection("jdbc:default:connection");
289            Statement s = conn.createStatement();
290        )
291        {
292            SlotTester t = conn.unwrap(SlotTester.class);
293
294            String query =
295                "SELECT" +
296                "  to_char(stamp, 'DAY') AS day," +
297                "  stamp" +
298                " FROM" +
299                "  generate_series(" +
300                "   timestamp 'epoch', timestamp 'epoch' + interval 'P6D'," +
301                "   interval 'P1D'" +
302                "  ) AS s(stamp)";
303
304            try ( Portal p = t.unwrapAsPortal(s.executeQuery(query)) )
305            {
306                Projection proj = p.tupleDescriptor();
307
308                /*
309                 * A quick glance shows this project(...) to be unneeded, as the
310                 * query's TupleDescriptor already has exactly these columns in
311                 * this order, and could be used below directly. On the other
312                 * hand, this line will keep things working if someone later
313                 * changes the query, reordering these columns or adding
314                 * to them, and it may give a more explanatory exception if
315                 * a change to the query does away with an expected column.
316                 */
317                proj = proj.project("day", "stamp");
318
319                List<TupleTableSlot> fetched = p.fetch(FORWARD, ALL);
320
321                List<String> results = new ArrayList<>();
322
323                proj.applyOver(fetched, c ->
324                {
325                    /*
326                     * This loop demonstrates a straightforward use of two
327                     * Adapters and a lambda with two parameters to go through
328                     * the retrieved rows.
329                     *
330                     * Note that applyOver does not, itself, iterate over the
331                     * rows; it supplies a Cursor object that can be iterated to
332                     * do that. This gives the lambda body of applyOver more
333                     * control over how that will happen.
334                     *
335                     * The Cursor object is mutated during iteration so the
336                     * same object represents each row in turn; the iteration
337                     * variable is simply the Cursor object itself, so does not
338                     * need to be used. Once the "unnamed variable" _ is more
339                     * widely available (Java 21 has it, with --enable-preview),
340                     * it will be the obvious choice for the iteration variable
341                     * here.
342                     *
343                     * Within the loop, the cursor represents the single current
344                     * row as far as its apply(...) methods are concerned.
345                     *
346                     * Other patterns, such as the streams API, can also be used
347                     * (starting with a stream of the cursor object itself,
348                     * again for each row), but can involve more fuss when
349                     * checked exceptions are involved.
350                     */
351                    for ( Cursor __ : c )
352                    {
353                        c.apply(TEXT, LDT,         // the adapters
354                            (     v0,  v1 ) ->     // the fetched values
355                            results.add(v0 + " | " + v1.getDayOfWeek())
356                        );
357                    }
358
359                    /*
360                     * This equivalent loop uses two lambdas in curried style
361                     * to do the same processing of the same two columns. That
362                     * serves no practical need in this example; a perfectly
363                     * good method signature for two reference columns was seen
364                     * above. This loop illustrates the technique for combining
365                     * the available methods when there isn't one that exactly
366                     * fits the number and types of the target columns.
367                     */
368                    for ( Cursor __ : c )
369                    {
370                        c.apply(TEXT,
371                                v0 ->
372                            c.apply(LDT,
373                                    v1 ->
374                                results.add(v0 + " | " + v1.getDayOfWeek())
375                            )
376                        );
377                    }
378
379                    return null;
380                });
381
382                return results.iterator();
383            }
384        }
385    }
386
387    /**
388     * Test retrieval of a PostgreSQL array as a multidimensional Java array.
389     */
390    @Function(schema="javatest")
391    public static Iterator<String> javaMultiArrayTest()
392    throws SQLException, ReflectiveOperationException
393    {
394        Connection conn = getConnection("jdbc:default:connection");
395        SlotTester t = conn.unwrap(SlotTester.class);
396
397        String query =
398            "VALUES (" +
399            " CAST ( '{1,2}'                 AS      int8 [] ), " +
400            " CAST ( '{{1},{2}}'             AS      int4 [] ), " +
401            " CAST ( '{{{1,2,3}}}'           AS      int2 [] ), " +
402            " CAST ( '{{{{1},{2},{3}}}}'     AS  \"char\" [] ), " + // ASCII
403            " CAST ( '{{{{{1,2,3}}}}}'       AS    float8 [] ), " +
404            " CAST ( '{{{{{{1},{2},{3}}}}}}' AS    float4 [] ), " +
405            " CAST ( '{{{{{t},{f},{t}}}}}'   AS   boolean [] ), " +
406            " CAST ( '{{''epoch''}}'         AS timestamp [] )  " +
407            "), (" +
408            " '{NULL}', NULL, NULL, NULL, '{{{{{1,NULL,3}}}}}', NULL, NULL," +
409            " '{{NULL}}'" +
410            ")";
411
412        Portal p = t.unwrapAsPortal(conn.createStatement().executeQuery(query));
413        Projection proj = p.tupleDescriptor();
414
415        List<TupleTableSlot> tups = p.fetch(FORWARD, ALL);
416
417        List<String> result = new ArrayList<>();
418
419        /*
420         * Then just use the right adapter for each column.
421         */
422        proj.applyOver(tups, c ->
423        {
424            for ( Cursor __ : c )
425            {
426                c.apply(I8x1, I4x2, I2x3, I1x4, F8x5, F4x6, Bx5, DTx2,
427                    (     v0,   v1,   v2,   v3,   v4,   v5,  v6,   v7 ) ->
428                    result.addAll(List.of(
429                        Arrays.toString(v0), deepToString(v1), deepToString(v2),
430                           deepToString(v3), deepToString(v4), deepToString(v5),
431                           deepToString(v6), deepToString(v7),
432                           v7[0][0].orElse(LocalDateTime.MAX).getMonth() + ""
433                    ))
434                );
435            }
436            return null;
437        });
438
439        return result.iterator();
440    }
441
442    /**
443     * An adapter to compose over another one, adding some wanted behavior.
444     *
445     * There should eventually be a built-in set of composing adapters like
446     * this available for ready use, and automatically composed for you by an
447     * adapter manager when you say "I want an adapter for this PG type to this
448     * Java type and behaving this way."
449     *
450     * Until then, let this illustrate the simplicity of writing one.
451     */
452    public static class NullReplacingDouble extends AsDouble<Double>
453    {
454        private final double replacement;
455
456        @Override
457        public boolean canFetchNull() { return true; }
458
459        @Override
460        public double fetchNull(Attribute a)
461        {
462            return replacement;
463        }
464
465        // It would be nice to let this method be omitted and this behavior
466        // assumed, in a composing adapter with the same type for return and
467        // parameter. Maybe someday.
468        public double adapt(Attribute a, double value)
469        {
470            return value;
471        }
472
473        private static final Adapter.Configuration config =
474            Adapter.configure(NullReplacingDouble.class, null);
475
476        NullReplacingDouble(AsDouble<?> over, double valueForNull)
477        {
478            super(config, over);
479            replacement = valueForNull;
480        }
481    }
482
483    /**
484     * Another example of a useful composing adapter that should eventually be
485     * part of a built-in set.
486     */
487    public static class AsOptional<T> extends As<Optional<T>,T>
488    {
489        // canFetchNull isn't needed; its default in As<?,?> is true.
490
491        @Override
492        public Optional<T> fetchNull(Attribute a)
493        {
494            return Optional.empty();
495        }
496
497        public Optional<T> adapt(Attribute a, T value)
498        {
499            return Optional.of(value);
500        }
501
502        private static final Adapter.Configuration config =
503            Adapter.configure(AsOptional.class, null);
504
505        /*
506         * This adapter may be composed over any Adapter<T,?>, including those
507         * of primitive types as well as the reference-typed As<T,?>. When
508         * constructed over a primitive-returning adapter, values will be boxed
509         * when passed to adapt().
510         */
511        AsOptional(Adapter<T,?> over)
512        {
513            super(config, over, null);
514        }
515    }
516
517    /**
518     * A surprisingly useful composing adapter that should eventually be
519     * part of a built-in set.
520     *<p>
521     * Surprisingly useful, because although it "does" nothing, composing it
522     * over any primitive adapter produces one that returns the boxed form, and
523     * Java null for SQL null.
524     */
525    public static class Identity<T> extends As<T,T>
526    {
527        // the inherited fetchNull returns null, which is just right
528
529        public T adapt(Attribute a, T value)
530        {
531            return value;
532        }
533
534        private static final Adapter.Configuration config =
535            Adapter.configure(Identity.class, null);
536
537        /*
538         * Another choice could be to restrict 'over' to extend Primitive, as
539         * there isn't much point composing this adapter over one of reference
540         * type ... unless you want Java null for SQL null and the 'over'
541         * adapter produces something else.
542         */
543        Identity(Adapter<T,?> over)
544        {
545            super(config, over, null);
546        }
547    }
548
549    /**
550     * Test retrieving results from a query using the PG-model API and returning
551     * them to the caller using the legacy JDBC API.
552     * @param query a query producing some number of columns
553     * @param adapters an array of strings, twice the number of columns,
554     * supplying a class name and static field name for the ugly temporary
555     * {@code adapterPlease} method, one such pair for each result column
556     */
557    @Function(
558        schema = "javatest", type = "pg_catalog.record", variadic = true,
559        onNullInput = RETURNS_NULL, provides = "modelToJDBC"
560    )
561    public static ResultSetProvider modelToJDBC(String query, String[] adapters)
562    throws SQLException, ReflectiveOperationException
563    {
564        Connection conn = getConnection("jdbc:default:connection");
565        SlotTester t = conn.unwrap(SlotTester.class);
566        Portal p = t.unwrapAsPortal(conn.createStatement().executeQuery(query));
567        TupleDescriptor td = p.tupleDescriptor();
568
569        if ( adapters.length != 2 * td.size() )
570            throw new SQLException(String.format(
571                "query makes %d columns so 'adapters' should have %d " +
572                "elements, not %d", td.size(), 2*td.size(), adapters.length));
573
574        if ( Arrays.stream(adapters).anyMatch(Objects::isNull) )
575            throw new SQLException("adapters array has null element");
576
577        As<?,?>[] resolved = new As<?,?>[ td.size() ];
578
579        for ( int i = 0 ; i < resolved.length ; ++ i )
580        {
581            Adapter<?,?> a =
582                t.adapterPlease(adapters[i<<1], adapters[(i<<1) + 1]);
583            if ( a instanceof As<?,?> )
584                resolved[i] = (As<?,?>)a;
585            else
586                resolved[i] = new Identity(a);
587        }
588
589        return new ResultSetProvider.Large()
590        {
591            @Override
592            public boolean assignRowValues(ResultSet out, long currentRow)
593            throws SQLException
594            {
595                if ( 0 == currentRow )
596                {
597                    int rcols = out.getMetaData().getColumnCount();
598                    if ( td.size() != rcols )
599                        throw new SQLException(String.format(
600                            "query makes %d columns but result descriptor " +
601                            "has %d", td.size(), rcols));
602                }
603
604                /*
605                 * This example will fetch one tuple at a time here in the
606                 * ResultSetProvider. This is a low-level interface to Postgres.
607                 * In the SFRM_ValuePerCall protocol that ResultSetProvider
608                 * supports, a fresh call from Postgres is made to retrieve each
609                 * row. The Portal lives in a memory context that persists
610                 * across the multiple calls, but the fetch result tups only
611                 * exist in a child of the SPI context set up for each call.
612                 * So here we only fetch as many tups as we can use to make one
613                 * result row.
614                 *
615                 * If the logic involved fetching a bunch of rows and processing
616                 * those into Java representations with no further dependence on
617                 * the native tuples, then of course that could be done all in
618                 * advance.
619                 */
620                List<TupleTableSlot> tups = p.fetch(FORWARD, 1);
621                if ( 0 == tups.size() )
622                    return false;
623
624                TupleTableSlot tts = tups.get(0);
625
626                for ( int i = 0 ; i < resolved.length ; ++ i )
627                {
628                    Object o = tts.get(i, resolved[i]);
629                    try
630                    {
631                        out.updateObject(1 + i, o);
632                    }
633                    catch ( SQLException e )
634                    {
635                        try
636                        {
637                            out.updateObject(1 + i, o.toString());
638                        }
639                        catch ( SQLException e2 )
640                        {
641                            e.addSuppressed(e2);
642                            throw e;
643                        }
644                    }
645                }
646
647                return true;
648            }
649
650            @Override
651            public void close()
652            {
653                p.close();
654            }
655        };
656    }
657
658    /**
659     * A temporary test jig during TupleTableSlot development; intended
660     * to be used from a debugger.
661     */
662    @Function(schema="javatest", provides="tupleTableSlotTest")
663    public static void tupleTableSlotTest(
664        String query, String adpClass, String adpInstance)
665    throws SQLException, ReflectiveOperationException
666    {
667        new TupleTableSlotTest().testWith(query, adpClass, adpInstance);
668    }
669
670    As<?,?>      adpL;
671    AsLong<?>    adpJ;
672    AsDouble<?>  adpD;
673    AsInt<?>     adpI;
674    AsFloat<?>   adpF;
675    AsShort<?>   adpS;
676    AsChar<?>    adpC;
677    AsByte<?>    adpB;
678    AsBoolean<?> adpZ;
679
680    void testWith(String query, String adpClass, String adpInstance)
681    throws SQLException, ReflectiveOperationException
682    {
683        Connection c = getConnection("jdbc:default:connection");
684        SlotTester t = c.unwrap(SlotTester.class);
685
686        ResultSet rs = c.createStatement().executeQuery(query);
687        Portal p = t.unwrapAsPortal(rs);
688        TupleDescriptor td = p.tupleDescriptor();
689
690        List<TupleTableSlot> tups = p.fetch(FORWARD, ALL);
691
692        int ntups = tups.size();
693
694        boolean firstTime = true;
695
696        int form = 8; // set with debugger, 8 selects reference-typed adpL
697
698        boolean go; // true until set false by debugger each time through loop
699
700        /*
701         * Results from adapters of assorted types.
702         */
703        long    jj = 0;
704        double  dd = 0;
705        int     ii = 0;
706        float   ff = 0;
707        short   ss = 0;
708        char    cc = 0;
709        byte    bb = 0;
710        boolean zz = false;
711        Object  ll = null;
712
713        for ( TupleTableSlot tts : tups )
714        {
715            if ( firstTime )
716            {
717                firstTime = false;
718                Adapter a = t.adapterPlease(adpClass, adpInstance);
719                if ( a instanceof As )
720                    adpL = (As<?,?>)a;
721                else if ( a instanceof AsLong )
722                    adpJ = (AsLong<?>)a;
723                else if ( a instanceof AsDouble )
724                    adpD = (AsDouble<?>)a;
725                else if ( a instanceof AsInt )
726                    adpI = (AsInt<?>)a;
727                else if ( a instanceof AsFloat )
728                    adpF = (AsFloat<?>)a;
729                else if ( a instanceof AsShort )
730                    adpS = (AsShort<?>)a;
731                else if ( a instanceof AsChar )
732                    adpC = (AsChar<?>)a;
733                else if ( a instanceof AsByte )
734                    adpB = (AsByte<?>)a;
735                else if ( a instanceof AsBoolean )
736                    adpZ = (AsBoolean<?>)a;
737            }
738
739            for ( Attribute att : tts.descriptor() )
740            {
741                go = true;
742                while ( go )
743                {
744                    go = false;
745                    try
746                    {
747                        switch ( form )
748                        {
749                        case 0: jj = tts.get(att, adpJ); break;
750                        case 1: dd = tts.get(att, adpD); break;
751                        case 2: ii = tts.get(att, adpI); break;
752                        case 3: ff = tts.get(att, adpF); break;
753                        case 4: ss = tts.get(att, adpS); break;
754                        case 5: cc = tts.get(att, adpC); break;
755                        case 6: bb = tts.get(att, adpB); break;
756                        case 7: zz = tts.get(att, adpZ); break;
757                        case 8: ll = tts.get(att, adpL); break;
758                        }
759                    }
760                    catch ( AdapterException e )
761                    {
762                        System.out.println(e);
763                    }
764                }
765            }
766        }
767    }
768}
